subject: Psychology
title: The Mere Exposure Effect
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Mere Exposure Effect usable.

hook.text: A song you hated grows on you after hearing it ten times. Familiarity breeds not contempt, but affection.

buildup.text: Robert Zajonc demonstrated that repeated exposure to a stimulus increases liking, even without conscious memory of it.

discovery.text: In experiments, people preferred Chinese characters they'd seen before â€” even when they couldn't recall seeing them.

twist.text: The effect works for faces too. We prefer faces we've seen before, which partly explains the proximity effect.

climax.text: Advertisers exploit this relentlessly. Brand familiarity equals brand preference, even without product knowledge.

punchline.text: The more you see something, the more you like it.

quiz.question: What does the mere exposure effect predict?
options: Repeated exposure to something increases liking for it
Seeing something often makes you dislike it
Exposure has no effect on preferences
